text: To clarify what may have been misconstrued: I'm of course not presuming to advise anyone on how to describe their own illness. For others, including those of us who are writers or broadcasters, I'm suggesting we think a bit more closely about the words we choose. - fin-
author: NPRmelissablock

text: yep
author: NPRmelissablock

text:
"...or somehow society has a stigma on them for not 'fighting to the bitter end.'"
She was clearly pained as she talked about this. I can only imagine how painful these choices are for patients & their families, and hope the language we use doesn't make those choices any harder./
author: NPRmelissablock

text: She continued, "As someone treating kids with cancer, I feel like every time I hear that, it's a little painful for me. Because then I think of all the patients that we take care of who feel like they're losing. Or that they're giving up..."
author: NPRmelissablock

text: One of the doctors told me this, and it's stuck with me ever since. "The motto in cancer treatment and cancer survival has really been 'Fight.' Every slogan you hear is, 'I want to keep fighting, we need to beat the disease.' As if everything is a winnable situation."
author: NPRmelissablock

text: I'm reminded of a story I did years ago about a pediatric palliative care team at Children's Hospital in Philadelphia. The team takes care of children who are dying, and whose parents have to make excruciating decisions at the end of life.  They do remarkable, sensitive work.
author: NPRmelissablock

text: How many times have we heard or read that someone "lost the battle" with cancer? What message does that send to patients, to families, struggling with agonizing choices?
author: NPRmelissablock

text: ... I am always unsettled by the "cancer as battle" metaphor and the language we use to describe it. I'm thinking of those who have decided to stop treatment, and who may be seen as having given up the fight, or surrendering.  Of not doing enough.
author: NPRmelissablock

text: A few thoughts about Alex Trebek and his statement that he plans to "fight" and "beat" his stage 4 pancreatic cancer. First, of course I hope that he succeeds, and that his treatments prove effective. I deeply respect his decision to share his diagnosis publicly. But...
author: NPRmelissablock

text: Yep. And we've all been there. #ATCstrong
